context: The Finnish word 'metsä' means forest or woods in English. It is a common noun referring to an area covered with trees and vegetation, typically larger than just a few individual trees. In Finnish grammar, 'metsä' follows the regular declension pattern for consonant-stem nouns: metsä (nominative), metsän (genitive), metsään (illative), metsässä (inessive), etc. It can be used in various contexts to describe natural forested areas or metaphorically to represent wilderness, nature, or tranquility.
